educational_objective: Diagnose acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis.
question_text: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for acute left knee pain.A radiograph of the left knee is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following diagnoses is suggested by these findings?
critique: Acute calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystal arthritis (pseudogout) (Option A) is suggested by the history of acute monoarticular arthritis and radiographic findings showing CPP deposition in the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) of the left knee. Chondrocalcinosis is suggestive but not diagnostic of acute CPP crystal arthritis and is commonly seen in the articular cartilage of the knee and the wrists (triangular fibrocartilage). Acute CPP crystal arthritis typically presents as a monoarticular inflammatory arthritis characterized by the sudden onset of swelling, pain, loss of function, tenderness, and warmth of the affected joint. Definitive diagnosis requires identification of CPP crystals (and leukocytes) in synovial fluid.
